data.title: Copy-Paste broken into VSCode Integrated Terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Insiders Version: 1.9.0
- OS Version: OSX 10.10.2

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Copy & Paste text from the VS Code Editor window into the Integrated Terminal
 -> Nothing appears to be pasted!
2.  Press `Enter` -> the next line shows the text that was pasted before

This problem came up only after updating VSCode Insiders to the latest version yesterday. I am not using any special `tmux` session.

data.title: Keep scroll position stable when closing an inactive tab
data.body:
Fixes #13001

Will no longer automatically reveal the active tab when closing inactive tabs in the tab well when performing the following actions:
* Clicking tab close button
* Middle-clicking tabs
* Right-click menu -> Close 

Also reveals the active tab when focus is regained on the editor.

![vscode-closing-tab-well](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19281538/23584448/033ee344-019d-11e7-9e14-9d55584fabd5.gif)

data.title: VS Code rendering problem causing low mouse accuracy...
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 64bit on VirtualBox with Guest Additions installed.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open file with content
2. Click on a specific place in the text
3. Your cursor will be to the left and up a bit from where you originally clicked
4. The window appears to actually be larger than what's being rendered on the screen

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1048286/22171645/ea6e96e6-df57-11e6-8ba8-64b804fdd909.png)

In the screenshot, the middle of the green circle is where I actually have to click in order to resize the window. So if I click where the corner is actually rendered at, it will register the click just above the smiley face. The same distance from where the corner is rendered at to where it actually is.

data.title: Context based user snippet priority
data.body:
vscode: 1.8.1

When there is an user snippet, it should take precedent over available completion.

For example: `import`.
I like to define a snippet as follow:

```js
{
	"import": {
		"prefix": "import",
		"body": [
                  "import { $2 } from '$1'",
                  "$0"
                ]
	}
}
```

Currently, typing import (or "i", "im", "imp" and so on), would complete the "import" keyword.
IMO it should trigger the snippet instead.

COPY COMMENT FROM BELOW:
Actually, using `editor.snippetSuggestions: 'top'` is not optimal. It should go below instance property and above keywords. e.g.:

```ts
import^  // snippet "import" should go before the import keyword

function foo(option: SomeFooOptions) { ... }
foo({ ^ } // properties in "SomeFooOptions" should go before user snippets.
```

Also, it would be better if we can specify the context for when the user snippet should be available.

data.title: Fixes md preview to editor sync when before first element in preview
Reindent all lines
data.body: Reindent all lines based on the language specific indentation rules.

data.title: New tasks.json variable request for re-running tasks.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 pro

Feature request: essentially an additional boolean variable supported in the tasks.json file which when set would stop vscode from prompting you to terminate an existing task (see below) when trying to re-run a task. 

![Alt Text](http://i.imgur.com/7kvh9ta.png "grr")
Instead running a new task while another still exists would first terminate the existing, then cleanly run the new without presenting a jarring prompt.

Reasoning: I would like to be able to re-run a task without first terminating it, or being forced through this prompt.

data.title: "jump to bracket" doesn't scroll to reveal cursor
data.body:
- Have a file with some matched brackets:

```
function foo() {

}
```

- Scroll so that one bracket is out of the viewport
- Put the cursor on the other bracket and press cmd+shift+\

The cursor goes to the other bracket out of the viewport, but the editor doesn't scroll to bring it into the viewport. If I press an arrow key, then it's revealed.

data.title: Prompts aren't focused for keyboard selection.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 Pro

The default behaviour is for the focus is to remain on the editor and not move to the prompt for easy selection using the keyboard (i.e. left & right arrow keys). This forces users to have to reach for their mouse.

Example:
![Alt Text](http://i.imgur.com/7kvh9ta.png "grr")

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Do anything that causes a prompt to be displayed (i.e. try to run a task without terminating an existing task)
2. Result, focus returns to the text editor view and not to the prompt.

This would be really great if this could be implemented and I don't think anyone would disapprove.

Should we replace the users home directory path prefix for Recent files with `~/`? on Mac/Linux and `$\" or nothing on Windows?  Just an idea

data.title: Shortcuts with Italian key layout work randomly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.8.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 14.04 LTS (Dell Custom)
- System language: English US
- Keyboard: Standard Italian

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set keyboard layout (thorugh Ubuntu) to Italian - this is the standard setup of mine, since keyboard layout is Italian.

2. Go to File -> Preferences -> Keyboard shortcuts, and look for i.e. "Toggle new terminal" (that is Ctrl+` for US layout and Crtl+\ for Italian layout - they are on the same physical key, so I assume this is the rationale).

3. Execute the shortcut and (a) nothing happens or worse (b) something different from expected happens.

4. Set keyboard layout (thorugh Ubuntu) EN-US (it might work, sure, but it takes a bit, making it useless to use shortcuts)

5. The command works, if the Italian-keyboard key combination is pressed.

To my knowledge and limited testing, this is the only way to make some shortcuts work.

data.title: Fix markdown view sync for frontmatter
data.body:
Fixes #18946

**Bug**
The markdown preview and editor syncronization is currently thrown off by yaml frontmatter. All the line numbers generated are off by the size of the frontmatter

**Fix**
For the generated line numbers, add an initial line offset to account for the size of the remove frontmatter.

data.title: Problem with unreadable texts in tabs due to low contrast, brightness
data.body:
Most themes (and I think it's not their fault) use in effect very unreadable colors with low brightness/contrast ratios for inactive tabs, since they are faded using opacity. This is very inconvenient - not being able to clearly see what files are open and finding easily the ones I want. Especially if you are working at night with decreased screen brightness or in bright light (in the morning).

Currently:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/821272/22165447/1ee1347a-df5c-11e6-8096-e2d825a38cf1.png)

Illutration how the issue could be improved:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/821272/22165607/0f8b09b4-df5d-11e6-8fbf-74f14ff87329.png)

I am not proposing a solution, as I feel it may come from multiple directions e.g..:
- allow themes to customize tabs styling
- do not use opacity to fade inactive tab, highlight active tab by other means
- allows custom user styling of tabs...

data.title: Markdown view sync thrown off by frontmatter
[WelcomeUX] Interactive Playground: Click on File explorer, recent file opens
data.body:
Testing #18091

- Open the interactive playground
- Click on the icons in the side bar (Git, extensions, search, .. explorer)
- Notice that when you click on explorer, 
   - if no other file is open, then previously most recent opened file opens in a new editor.
   - if there was an editor with a file open, then that editor becomes the active editor

data.title: [WelcomeUX] Better grouping for actions that customize experience
data.body:
Testing #18091

The "Keyboard shortcuts" links takes you to the reference guide, but doesn't tell you how to change the keyboard binding.
There are 2 quicklinks about keyboard short cut, neither telling you how to change the keyboard binding.

How about having a new section called "Customize your VS Code" and add the below there
- Change Editor Theme
- Change Editor Settings
- Change Keyboard Bindings
- Map keyboard shortcuts to another editor's style

The Quick Links can have
- Interface Overview (which I'd rather name as "Visual Studio Code Overview". The current name is not intuitive)
- Reference guide for common keyboard shortcuts
- Show all commands
- Interactive playground

cc @bgashler1

data.title: [WelcomeUX] Create new file should make the overlay disappear
data.body:
Testing #18091 on OS X El Capitan

- Click on the interface overview and wait for the overlay to appear
- Use either the keyboard shortcut or the File menu to create a new file
- New file gets created and you can type there !! And overlay is still there too!

- Or use the command pallet to open a file (Cmd+P)
- The file opens and you can type!! And overlay is still there too!

data.title: [WelcomeUX] When overlay appears, can we get a blank editor behind it?
data.body: Testing #18091 on OS X El Capitan The text on the overlay fights for attention with the text under the overlay. Usually when websites have overlays, the background is greyed out/blurred and the text on the overlay can be clearly read.

data.title: [WelcomeUX] In lighter themes, need better color for the recent folder paths
data.body: Testing #18091 on OS X El Capitan In lighter themes (Light, Light+, Solarized Light etc.), the path to the recent folders disappear

data.title: [WelcomeUX]  Accessibilty for Welcome Page
data.body:
Testing #18091

On Mac you can use tab to navigate through the Quick Links in the Welcome page while you can't do that on Linux.

data.title: [WelcomeUX] Editor Theme, also tell me how do get there myself?
data.body:
Testing #18091 on OS X El Capitan

Clicking on "Editor theme" quick link opens the command pallet for user to change the theme.
But, this doesn't help the user learn how to do it the next time.

May be include the command (Preferences: Color Theme) in the text or the menu route 
Code -> Preferences -> Color Theme.

Same thing for "Show All Commands". We can include the keyboard shortcut there.
And for "Change Settings"
